title: Richard Rose (political scientist)
text:
Richard Rose (born 9 April 1933 in <a href="St%20Louis%2C%20Missouri">St Louis, Missouri</a>) is an American <a href="Political%20science">political scientist</a> who has been a professor of politics in Scotland since 1966. His research has included the <a href="The%20Troubles">Northern Ireland conflict</a>, <a href="enlargement%20of%20the%20European%20Union">enlargement of the European Union</a>, <a href="democratisation">democratisation</a>, <a href="policy%20transfer">policy transfer</a>, elections and voting.
Education.
Rose studied as an undergraduate at <a href="Johns%20Hopkins%20University">Johns Hopkins University</a>. His doctorate at the <a href="University%20of%20Oxford">University of Oxford</a>, entitled "The relation of socialist principles to British Labour foreign policy, 1945-51", was completed in 1960 
Academic career.
From 1961 to 1966, Rose was lecturer in government at the <a href="University%20of%20Manchester">University of Manchester</a>.
Since 1966, he has been based in Scotland, mostly as professor of politics at the <a href="University%20of%20Strathclyde">University of Strathclyde</a>, where in 1976 he founded the Centre for the Study of Public Policy, of which he is director. However, from 2005 to 2011, he was at the <a href="University%20of%20Aberdeen">University of Aberdeen</a> where he held the sixth century chair in politics.
Rose is an honorary vice president of the <a href="Political%20Studies%20Association">Political Studies Association</a>, which each year awards a prize in his name to a scholar under 40 years of age who has made a distinctive contribution to the study of British politics. Rose has an <a href="honorary%20doctorate">honorary doctorate</a> from <a href="%C3%96rebro%20University">Örebro University</a> in Sweden, a lifetime achievement award from the <a href="Policy%20Studies%20Organization">Policy Studies Organization</a>, and a career award from the 
He is a fellow, member, or honorary member of the <a href="American%20Academy%20of%20Arts%20and%20Sciences">American Academy of Arts and Sciences</a>, the <a href="British%20Academy">British Academy</a>, the <a href="Finnish%20Academy%20of%20Science%20and%20Letters">Finnish Academy of Science and Letters</a>, the <a href="Academy%20of%20Learned%20Societies%20for%20the%20Social%20Sciences">Academy of Learned Societies for the Social Sciences</a>, and the <a href="Royal%20Society%20of%20Edinburgh">Royal Society of Edinburgh</a>.
